discoveredAssets: localhost:5000 - Dalgona Challenges Platform (Flask/Werkzeug Python/3.13.3) - Port 5000 - Web Application
http://localhost:5000/ - Root endpoint (GET 200 OK) - Home page with challenge links
http://localhost:5000/xss12 - XSS Challenge endpoint (GET 200 OK) - XSS vulnerability challenge with 'name' parameter
http://localhost:5000/static/ - Static assets directory (CSS, images, favicon) - Returns 404 but individual assets accessible
/home/daytona/repo/src/ - Flask application source code and configuration - Contains app.py, constants.py, secret.txt, static assets, and check.js
Python flask process (PID 1732) - Running on 0.0.0.0:5000 with debug mode enabled

targets.objective: Test for XSS vulnerabilities, identify bypass methods for input blacklist (script, onload, onclick, onmouseover, single quote, forward slash), validate vulnerability to reflected XSS, attempt to retrieve flags from application
targets.rationale: Endpoint has intentional XSS vulnerability with weak blacklist-based filtering. X-XSS-Protection header is explicitly disabled. Input parameter 'name' is reflected in HTML without proper sanitization. This is a high-value target for XSS exploitation to demonstrate vulnerability class and retrieve sensitive flag data.

targets.objective: Analyze page rendering, check for client-side vulnerabilities, identify all referenced static resources, look for hidden endpoints or JavaScript-based routing
targets.rationale: Home page may contain additional endpoints or information. Should validate that all static resources are properly handled and check for any additional attack surface exposed through the interface.

targets.objective: Test for debug mode features, Werkzeug debugger access, potential code execution through debug interface, information disclosure from debug pages
targets.rationale: Application is running with Flask debug=True. Werkzeug debugger provides interactive console access if reachable, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution or sensitive information disclosure.

targets.objective: Analyze PhantomJS subprocess calls for command injection vulnerabilities, test for file path traversal in temporary file handling, validate sandbox escape possibilities
targets.rationale: Source code shows subprocess.Popen calls to phantomjs with file paths based on random hex generation. Temporary HTML files are created in static/ directory which is web-accessible, creating potential for race condition or path traversal attacks.

targets.objective: Retrieve flag data stored in plaintext, determine if accessible via web application path traversal or directory traversal vulnerabilities
targets.rationale: Secrets are stored in plaintext file on the filesystem. While not directly web-accessible through discovered paths, directory traversal or other path-based vulnerabilities could potentially expose this file.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] XSS Challenge endpoint (/xss12) intentionally vulnerable with weak blacklist-based input filtering - allows user input directly in HTML output
[CRITICAL] X-XSS-Protection header explicitly disabled (value: 0) on /xss12 endpoint, removing browser-based XSS protections
[CRITICAL] Application source code and secrets stored in accessible filesystem location (/home/daytona/repo/src/)
[HIGH] Flask application running with debug=True enabled, potentially providing debug console and detailed error pages
[HIGH] Application bound to 0.0.0.0 (all interfaces) on port 5000, not restricted to localhost despite being development app
[HIGH] Temporary files created with random names in static/ directory during XSS validation - potentially web-accessible race condition
[MEDIUM] Weak blacklist input filter uses simple string matching - can be bypassed with alternate HTML/JavaScript techniques
[MEDIUM] Server header reveals technology stack (Werkzeug/1.0.1, Python/3.13.3) for fingerprinting
[LOW] Only 2 routes implemented in application (/,/xss12) - simple attack surface
[LOW] Static assets directory lacks proper access controls but is not directly listable
